citation.article-title: Rearrangements of the species and genera of the phototrophic "purple nonsulfur bacteria."

p.s: Rhodobacter (Rho.do.bac'ter. Gr.n. rhodon rose; M. L.masc.n. bacter equivalent of Gr.neut.n. bakterion rod; M.L.masc.n. Rhodobacter red-colored rod)
The type species of Rhodobacter is Rhodobacter capsulatus (Molisch 1907) van Niel 1944 comb. nov.
Other species: Rhodobacter sphaeroides van Niel 1944 comb. nov., Rhodobacter sulfidophilus Hansen and Veldkamp 1973 comb. nov., and Rhodobacter adriaticus Neutzling et al. 1984 comb. nov.
All species were formerly included in the genus Rhodopseudomonas.
All species of this genus have very similar properties.
The cells are ovoid to rod shaped and motile or nonmotile, divide by binary fission, and have vesicular photosynthetic membranes.
All species require thiamine, and most of them require biotin and a different third vitamin as growth factors.
The three species analyzed reduce sulfate via 3'-phosphate adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate.
Bacteriochlorophyll a and carotenoids of the spheroidene group are present as photosynthetic pigments.
All species contain the large type of cytochrome c2 (Rhodobacter adriaticus has not been analyzed yet) and Q-10 as the sole quinone component.
The species are very similar according to 16s rRNA analyses and DNA-rRNA hybridization studies.
Differences occur in the oxidation products of sulfide, which is oxidized by all four species.
The species can also be differentiated by their lipid compositions.
Despite the small variation in their phenotypic properties, DNA-DNA hybridization shows only a low degree of homology among the DNA molecules of the different species.

A study of 17 strains of Rhodobacter capsulatus, Rhodobacter sphaeroides, and Rhodobacter sulfidophilus revealed levels of homology of less than 30% (one exception was a value of 40%) between DNA molecules of different species.
